spans.content: Company P/Company A is eliminated for 200.
Company P/Company B for an amount of 300 is not eliminated because B is consolidated with the equity method.
Company A/Company P is eliminated for 100.
All amounts in company B accounts are not integrated because of the equity method.
The annual profit of 200 splits into 120 and 80 for the two mid-year periods.

... and the cumulated losses are greater than the consolidated reserves of all the other companies of the group.
In consolidation, reserves can be negative because one company makes huge cumulative losses since a number of years.

Suppose parent company reserves are equal to zero and the only consolidated company is making losses since its first year consolidation. In such case we would get consolidated equity lower than statutory equity.

Bank account of company A being consolidated by the equity method, we don't have any cash in the cash flow statement.

The amount of 150 in the transfer column has nothing to do with dividends or interim dividends. We have seen several times that this column was used mainly for two reasons, either a decrease in percentage in company A or some elimination of group profit via the Reserves account.
The option d is not correct.

At this moment, the consolidated gain is X - 3520. But we also have to eliminate the goodwill for 300, giving a net consolidated gain of X - 3520 - 300 which must be equal to 200.
Equity value of company A is
[3000 + 1000 + 400 - 500]. Equity value of company B is
The impact on A and B consolidated reserves is

Year 1 closing assets and liabilities will not impact the cash flow statement because they have not been acquired. The only cash out to show is the acquisition price of the shares giving the control on that company.
A goodwill never appears in a cash flow statement. A goodwill is only a part of the transaction amount.
This amount of 400 corresponding to the acquisition price less the goodwill is also a part of the acquisition price. It doesn't appear in the cash flow statement.
Whatever the consolidation method may be or the percentage acquired, the only amount impacting the cash flow statement is the acquisition price.
The first step when deconsolidating a company is to consolidate that company with the equity method.

The second step consists in modifying the value to bring it to the statutory financial investment of 1800. This can be done by a debit 450 on the equity value and a credit 450 on a profit account. This last booking is the answer.
The indirect group financial percentage in company A is
We first have to evaluate the consolidated equity of the subgroup which is
But this profit has to be decreased by the 500 goodwill attached to the
shares, which gives a final profit of X - 3852 - 500 that must be equal to 300.

We have seen several times through our different examples that when a company is consolidated with a percentage X until a shareholder decides to sell a percentage of Y, the following part of consolidated reserves, that is "consolidated reserves * (Y / X)" are transferred from the concerned company to the shareholder.
In our case, we speak about a ratio of
which applies to the remaining consolidated reserves
. Indeed, dividends paid must be deducted because already transferred (paid) to the shareholder.
